headline.main-hed: Israel Crackdown on Hamas Shows New Path

alt-summary-body.p: Israel widened its crackdown against Hamas on Wednesday, detaining 72 people and striking at its financial network in a further indication that Israel's tolerance for letting the Palestinian militant group operate on its borders is ending.

headline.main-hed: Israel Crackdown on Hamas Shows New Path

summary-body.p: Israel widened its crackdown against Hamas, detaining 72 people and striking at its financial network in a further indication that Israel's tolerance for letting the Palestinian militant group operate on its borders is ending.

headline.main-hed: Israel Crackdown on Hamas Shows New Path
headline.deck: Netanyahu Steps Up West Bank Raids and Arrests in Response to Alleged Abduction, as Tacit Truce With Islamists Crumbles

article-body.byline: By Nicholas Casey and Joshua Mitnick

media.media-caption: Israeli soldiers question Palestinians in Tapuah, in the West Bank, during a search operation on Wednesday for three missing Israelis.

article-body.p: GAZA CITY—Israel widened its crackdown against Hamas on Wednesday, detaining 72 people and striking at its financial network in a further indication that Israel's tolerance for letting the Palestinian militant group operate on its borders is ending.

The Israeli military operation, in response to what its government said was Hamas's kidnapping of three young Israelis last week, has also raised tensions between the two rival Palestinian factions and risks sinking their newly formed unity government.

For nearly two years, Israel and Hamas have lived under a tacit truce by which Israel allowed a disarmed wing of the Palestinian group to operate in the West Bank, as the Islamist group's militants controlled the Gaza Strip.

That equation changed this month when Hamas blessed a unity government of the Palestinian Authority, bringing it into mainstream politics for the first time in seven years and setting the stage for an election. Then three Israeli teenagers disappeared last week, for which Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's government holds Hamas responsible.

Dore Gold, Mr. Netanyahu's foreign-policy adviser, said the alleged abduction proved "the school of thought in the West that Hamas was moderating" was wrong. After Hamas acquiesced to the unity government, "there was a sense in Israel that the quiet of 2012 and 2013 was coming to an end."

Hamas argues that Israel is using allegations of kidnapping as an excuse to crack down on it and stymie the election. Ahmed Yousef, a prominent Hamas adviser in Gaza, said he spent years convincing the Islamists to end suicide attacks and sustain a cease-fire with Israel. He said Mr. Netanyahu was now trying to inflame the situation.
The disappearance of the Israeli teenagers, last seen when they were hitchhiking near the West Bank city Bethlehem on June 12, has created a political crisis on both sides of the conflict.
Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas, who is backed by Hamas's rival, the secular Fatah party, condemned the alleged kidnappers on Wednesday and pledged to hold those responsible to account.

"Whoever did this wanted to destroy us," Mr. Abbas said from Saudi Arabia in a speech broadcast on Palestinian television. "We are coordinating with [Israel] in order to return those youths, because they are human beings and we want to protect the lives of human beings."
Hamas, which generally decries cooperation between Israel and Palestinian security forces, criticized Mr. Abbas's comments as "harmful to Palestinian interests."

Israel was tense this week, as the government called up military reservists as each development in its West Bank search operation ricocheted through social media. On Wednesday, two rockets hit Israel, one of them damaging a home.

In response to the alleged kidnappings, Israel's military has launched its most extensive military operation in years, raiding the cities of Hebron, Nablus and Ramallah and detaining a total of more than 250 Palestinian suspects, including Hamas's top West Bank leadership.

Israel deployed new checkpoints and barbed wire barriers that are reminiscent of former Prime Minister Ariel Sharon's strategy during the Palestinian uprising in 2002. On Wednesday, military officials said they confiscated cash and shut down radio transmitters that they said were broadcasting pro-Hamas propaganda. The military also said it seized arms and explosives.

In another sign that understandings between Hamas and Israel were breaking down, The military said on Wednesday that it had rearrested 51 former Palestinian prisoners that it had freed as part of a 2011 prisoner swap for an Israel soldier, Gilad Schalit, who was held by Hamas-allied militants in Gaza for five years.

"What you are seeing is acts of collective punishment," said Mustafa Barghouti, a physician and leader of a political party who said he was blocked by Israeli soldiers from reaching a patient on Tuesday in Hebron.
Dr. Barghouti fears if the crackdown continues, the Palestinian Authority will have difficulty maintaining order and widespread violence could ensue.

The Palestinian Authority this month swore in a new cabinet of technocrats whose goal was to put Hamas and Fatah under common leadership and move toward the new election, which would be the first since 2006.

But with much of Hamas's leadership detained—and blamed by Israel for the alleged abductions—the conflict leaves the fate of the Palestinian unity government in doubt, many Palestinians and Israelis agree.
In forming the new cabinet, Mr. Abbas had pledged that despite the participation of Hamas, which doesn't recognize Israel, the new government did so and was committed to peace.
If Israel's accusation that Hamas was behind the kidnapping is true, "it could mean the end of the unity government," said Yossi Alpher, a former Mossad intelligence officer.
"The unity government really wasn't working before this, so its even more unclear how it will work after this," he said.

Ghassan Khatiab Palestinian politician and academic, said the alleged abduction potentially leaves Mr. Abbas politically weakened by Hamas. "Before the kidnapping Abbas had the upper hand, this weakens his position internationally,'' Mr. Khatib said.
Write to Nicholas Casey at nicholas.casey@wsj.com
